modules.description: This module constructs and manages DHCP server configurations by parsing ISC dhcpd.conf files or building configurations directly from parameters. It works with IP addresses, MAC addresses, DHCP options, and network prefixes to define server behavior, including lease times, address ranges, and host-specific settings. Concrete use cases include initializing a DHCP server with a predefined configuration file or programmatically creating configurations for dynamic network environments.

This module processes incoming DHCP packets, determining whether they are relevant to the server and producing a reply or update action based on the current lease database. It operates on DHCP packets, MAC addresses, and monotonic time values, returning structured outcomes like replies, warnings, or lease database updates. It is used in the server’s main loop to handle packet input and decide the appropriate response without performing any IO.

This module provides operations for managing DHCP lease records, including time-based lease manipulation (extension, expiration checks), database maintenance (garbage collection, lease replacement), and IP address allocation. It works with lease records containing timestamps, client identifiers, and IPv4 addresses, along with lease databases that track dynamic address assignments. These functions support critical DHCP server tasks like handling lease lifetimes, resolving client address requests, and ensuring efficient reuse of expired or freed IP addresses.

The module implements a DHCP server with submodules for configuration management, lease handling, and packet processing. It works with IP and MAC addresses, DHCP options, lease records, and network prefixes to manage dynamic address assignment and server behavior. Concrete use cases include parsing dhcpd.conf files, managing lease lifetimes and allocations, and processing DHCP requests to generate server responses.
